videos.title: Lexus LFA | A Proper Goodbye

sections.title: Intro
sections.content: (gentle piano music) (car engine revving)

sections.title: The Story of the LFA Owner
sections.content:
- I'm JR Smart, President and
CEO of Smart Motors Toyota. As a young child, I was enamored
of all the new vehicles. My father was a dealer,
his father was a dealer, so I'm a third generation dealer now. For me it really boils down to the people that are in this business. I have spent a lot of
time working side by side with technicians, with parts
people, with salespeople, on my way up, putting together a
fantastic team of people that have a shared passion
for the automobile industry as I do. Growing up, I accompanied
my father to the dealership on many occasions and learned
by working closely with him, working at his side, he taught me the value
of honesty, integrity, all those things really come
into play in this business, particularly because it
gets a bad rap sometimes. My grandfather started
this business in 1908. He worked out of his
grandfather's livery business, so actually we're a
little over 112 years old. Along the way, we've had
28 different franchises and 26 of those are no longer
here, they're long gone. We picked up the Toyota franchise in 1966 and coincidentally enough, I was along with my father
when he penned the deal with Toyota on that fateful day. Fast forward to today, I've been involved in
racing for over 40 years. Currently, I drive a Formula
Atlantic, Toyota-powered, and also have a Mazda-powered
Formula Atlantic, but Toyota has a strong relationship with the racing world as well. At one point, Toyota had
approached me to purchase an LFA, never dreamed that I
would purchase that car, I just kind of put it out of my mind and I'd had heard that they
had the leasing program and I was not a fan of that
so why would I do that? But then as time went
on and they relaxed that and started offering them for sale, it started to make a
little more sense to me and it built up in me, let's say that. One of their representatives, man by the name of Mr. Paul, I believe, came to my office, brought
his books and colored charts and so forth with him and we went

sections.title: Interior Impressions
sections.content:
(gentle music) - The interior of the LFA. This was a new direction for the brand and they wanted to represent the change in quality and craftsmanship and when you look at this,
with all the years removed, you can tell how they've
carried over bits and pieces and added them to cars
like the RC, the GSF, and of course the LC 500
is mostly representative of what they've done in
terms of leathers, fabrics, build quality, handles,
alloys, it's all here, with the exception there is
far more carbon fiber in here and that is the big differentiator
in the build of this. The entire tub, the driver
occupant cell is all CFRP. Now, the details, you have
carbon fiber on the sills, most of the door material
has this glossy carbon fiber, and of course, if you
were optioning this out, there were 13 different
ways you can do Alcantara, you could do leather color
stitching and all the buttons. Everything in here feels
like it's precision designed and that's really what this car was about. In terms of using this, you see the traditional Lexus
moving motorized gauge cluster that has been carried in
all the F products so far, you have a carbon fiber key,
yes, you have to turn a key, we place this in. To start the car, you
have the parking brake which is electronic, you
have two paddles here. To go into neutral, you pull them both towards you and then you can start the
car with the start button on the steering wheel, (car engine revving) but we'll talk about driving it later. When you grab the steering wheel, it's got a really decent amount of grip because the leather area is
where you're supposed to grab, it's got alloy pedals in it, one of my biggest complaints about this, and Ferrari does the same thing, the pedals are attached to
the column, not the wheel. So if you're getting to
the point of crossed over, or if you're starting
to lose control of it and you wanna upshift to
kind of stabilize the car, you have to take your hands off the wheel and it's one of the most
frustrating parts

sections.title: The Lexus Dealer and Service Options
sections.content:
(adventurous music) - So we've been transported
to Arlington Lexus, because if you have an LFA this is where you're
gonna have to service it here in the Midwest. This is Randy Romans, one of the owners of the Roman
Group's personal automobile and it only has like 75 miles on it. - Yeah, and even JR who's
matte black LFA we had, he would have to take
it to a Lexus dealership and part of the experience
of owning a Lexus is coming to like a
flagship store like this, when you see it from the outside, when you come flying
in on your private jet, it looks like a palace, the showroom is ridiculous, the theater, all the little amenities
that they pack in here, this is what they're trying to
do is make you feel special. - These two dealers are best in breed, they are the best examples of
a Lexus and Toyota dealership, and this is the experience
you should expect. - And if I had an LFA, this
is exactly what I'd want. But just briefly to talk about this; if you're gonna do
things like oil changes, you could bring it to
a dealership like this who is very competent to do it. But if you need any serious work, it's going to be
transported to California, or if you're in Europe, it's going to GAZOO Racing in
Cologne to do all that work. This is a highly specialized car and when you look at it front to back, you're gonna start to understand why as we bore you for the next 72 hours talking about every single detail you've probably never heard before and hopefully, if you
know a lot about this, you'll learn something. - So let's start with the
development story of this car,

sections.title: The Development Story and Toyota F1
sections.content:
- So let's start with the
development story of this car, and like any good story,
it started in a bar. - Oh, you're kidding. - No, it's very true, and instead of getting fired, his boss asked him you want, so Tanahashi, what do you want in a car? What is your dream? And I wanna to build a sports car. And after a year of
research and development and product planning, they came up with this thing. - So Haruhiko Tanahashi, he was kind of in product planner future planning for these types of cars, and it was in the back
of his mind for a while. And when he pitched this idea. - [Jack] He didn't wanna
build another minivan? - No, he didn't wanna build something, I'm sure obviously if you're an engineer, you wanna do something out of the box. So after this they
started this whole plan. And over the course of
the year it went through what do we wanna do? He had a diary of the entire process and one of the things they decided right away early on is
it wasn't just gonna be some like four cylinder
eco pile piece of sh**, it was gonna be a real
sports car high end, they did not want a baby like
Corolla turned sports car, this was gonna be a bespoke machine. So by the end of the year, they kind of had an idea
of what they wanted to do. Toyota was in Formula One, this was phasing out the
V10 days into the V8s, that was what they were going for and they planned on doing a V10. Now, as time went on, he was promoted to chief
engineer of this project, he oversaw the LFA works, which you're gonna get into, but the main thing that
he wanted to instill was he didn't wanna make this
all about the engine first, he wanted to make it
chassis and suspension first because he had patents in
twin tube damper technology and some chassis components so his roots were in making a solid car. - This car was suspension first. We all think of the V10, but at its core this
car is meant to handle, his philosophy behind that
was the hand of Buddha, he wanted a car that
communicated with you, that coddled

sections.title: Switching to Carbon Fiber and Parts Costs
sections.content:
They had--
- A Mercedes. And so this car set the groundwork for things like your LC 500. - [Mark] Correct. - [Jack] The GSF and the RCF. - After about five years, they were pretty deep into the development and one of the controllers had
brought them into the office, and they kind of kicked around the idea of doing the body and carbon fiber, which they didn't wanna do because they didn't possess
the knowledge to do it. They didn't have the team, they didn't have the
foundry, they have the works, the autoclaving, they
didn't have any of it. So Tanahashi's San, he's like, yeah, let's stick with aluminum. The controller brought him
in and said, guess what? We're switching to CFRP and he is like, what was happening? We're almost done with this car. - If you think about it, Mark, most cars only have a five or
six year development period. Can you imagine you're almost done and your boss is like you
gotta throw it all out, we're starting over? That's what they did effectively. - That's what they did. And so he went and talked
to Fuji Heavy or Subaru, and was like we gotta
switch this car to CFRP, what do you think? What do you think the
development cycle is gonna be? And they're like that's
probably not a good idea 'cause it's gonna take at least 10 years, 10 year plan to get this developed and he's like, well,
we don't have 10 years, we have like a year. So they worked on this and
they figured out how to do it, bring in autoclaves and mind you, none of the
craftsmen that they had there ever worked with carbon
fiber to this level before. They had Formula One and autoclaves and all the equipment to make race cars, but making a race car is far different than making carbon fiber
for a production car. So this is what they worked on, they figured it out, they figured out how to do
the robotics to cut the carbon and then to do the molding
process, to handle it, take a little hair dryers
to make sure it was perfect, a lot of trial and error, but obviously as you see
this even the

sections.title: Suspension, Brakes and Oil System
sections.content:
So, what else do we have on the front to talk about, Jack? - [Jack] So let's talk about
the suspension architecture. So you have an aluminum subframe and all of the suspension
components are aluminum, both the control arms
and knuckles, everything. - And the knuckles are forged and you have hollow arbs or
hollow sway bars to save weight. You have an aluminum steering rack, Jack. - You do. And this is an EPS unit, Mark. This is a column mounted
electric steering rack. - They all argued that they wanted a
hydraulic steering rack, however, you have to run hydraulic lines, you have to have a pump that creates some type of pumping losses, and when you look at how
tight this is in here, having this allowed them to lower this and you can see the shaft, the steering shaft is almost
touching the subframe. I mean, there's like
a millimeter in there. - [Jack] You're not working
on this car in your garage. - [Mark] No, you're not. And if you do I wanna see
that and I wanna talk to you. So the rack almost looks
like a manual steering rack, is super slim, super small, and then the power assist
unit is in the column itself. And because this car doesn't
need a lot of assistance, except when you're getting-- - [Jack] It's almost a manual rack. - Correct. It essentially turns itself off. We're not gonna get much more into that, let's talk about the dampers. - Okay, they are KYB dampers
and they are $9,500 a corner. - [Mark] Oh, that's it? - [Jack] Yes, real affordable. - [Mark] So the dampers
were co-developed with KYB on the LFA race car. So these look like race shocks, they have a remote or piggyback canister, this maintains pressure and it helps to reduce the
packaging of the shock. If you didn't have the remote canister, your shock body would be much longer. And since this is a smaller, more compact, double wishbone suspension, it gives them a lot more flexibility so the compression stroke can be, that oil and gas can be
offloaded to this canister, but the other benefit is heat m

sections.title: Rear Suspension, Cooling, Drivetrain, Transmission
sections.content:
- All right, Jack, in the
rear my favorite place to be. Let's start with cooling,
there's a lot to talk about. First, let's talk about what's back here. You have a transmission
cooler and you see the lines. The side panel has an
airflow duct that comes in, cools this, and then runs to the gearbox. The second piece of cooling that we see are the two rear bumper mounted radiators, all the coolant goes there and they have a low engine
mounted centrifugal pump that flows the coolant back here. And one of the reasons that
they put these radiators in the back instead of the front, - [Jack] Is you have limited surface area to work with in the front to actually get all the air in you need so much like in say a C7 Corvette or a lot of the race cars, you have to ducts on the
top of the rear fenders that feed air directly
into these heat exchangers. - [Mark] And the other
part was weight balance, moving more weight to the back, and why would they want to do that? - [Jack] So this car they were targeting a 48, 52 weight distribution. They wanted this to be rear weight biased because many professional drivers believe that is the ideal
balance to get a car to be. - [Mark] Instead of 50, 50. - [Jack] Yeah. - [Mark] So the next
thing, back to the cooling is this whole center tunnel here. This was used as a heat path
from the front to the back, there is an aluminum cover we have sitting on the floor there and we'll show you the footage, there are up kicks in this cooler that connect the two little pipes that move air up through this to move air over the exhaust manifold and then all the heat. There's also two of these
pipes under the hood, which you do not wanna fill up with water, but those blow air downward and all of the heat goes all
the way to the center tunnel and flows through the underbody
cover out the exhaust vents by the taillights. So I mean, I don't wanna
say it's over engineered, but it's so ridiculous what
they had to come up with and then also, because they wanted to

sections.title: Engine Design, Sound Design, Oiling System and Dry Sump
sections.content:
So this is the meat and
potatoes of the LFA, this is what people remember this car for and this is the V10. However, before we talk about this engine, let's talk about the hood and some of the carbon fiber body panels, like this hood here is $18,500. And the reason they went to
carbon throughout this car is obviously, as we talked about earlier, it's more rigid, but it also helped them
save 220 pounds of weight throughout the body of this car. - One of the big reasons besides weight is when they were doing their testing and they were building a race car with LFA is they couldn't get the
performance they wanted, the chassis wasn't right,
and the speed wasn't right, the lap times weren't
what they were expecting for the amount of work they put in. So they figured the 220
pounds would help them in terms of damping chassis setup, you'd have a more rigid chassis as well and then it would help out. - [Jack] I mean, it paid off. This was the fastest
production car around the ring when it did come out for
a short period of time. - Which means nothing, and I think the last thing we'll
talk about during the drive is really how it feels and that's what they
talked about development. It was about how the car
connected with you more than anything else and that is, - This V10. So everyone knows it's a V10 but here's some interesting
tidbits about it. This V10 is the size of a
V8 and the weight of a V6 and the way they accomplish that is a clever use of materials. So this has an aluminum block. The aluminum block was manufactured in Toyota's then defunct
Formula One factory. - Yeah, by the time they got around to making the engine, they had already been out of Formula One due to the economy mostly and the fact that they were
having some difficulties internally with it. So they had this high
tech, high end facility that they could do all their milling, all the engine manufacture process that they couldn't do
anywhere else in the company so it was a blessing in disguise. So they pre

about the chassis development and the handling, so the side effect is

machine like the F-type is. - It's more of a precision tool and the suspension stiffer
than I expect it to. It's definitely one of
those, you wanna catch it, or if you don't catch it it's going wrong, it's going sideways. And the next thing that I didn't realize and yes, we know this has a single clutch and the single clutch
feels very rudimentary compared to the new
systems, 10 years removed. But what it gives you is
the sense of mechanical feel and you hear the gearbox in the back when you shift gears, when it upshifts, there's like this shotgun

oh, there's a little robot and they're changing the gears and it sounds like a manual transmission, it feels like you're shifting

amount of theatrics when you drive this automobile from the way the gauge clusters, from the way it looks, to t

videos.title: Shelby GT350R Giveaway/Fundraiser Q&A with TRI Industries

sections.title: <Untitled Chapter 1>
sections.content: [Music] the Shelby gt350r this is a car that attracts children and adults alike I've yet to seen a vehicle of this type in recent history that will get people running after it like this is the damn ice cream truck on 150° day now the strange thing is this car is being given away via fundraiser by a local business that's only about 30 minutes away from me they contacted me via email and I said you know what's going on they said well we've seen your videos would you like to take a look at the car like well that sounds horrible but of course I did and after talking to them they're trying to to promote this car in line and there's a lot of skepticism so I went in there to talk to them firsthand to find out more about what they did and what this fundraiser is about so tell me a little bit about TR Industries try is a nonprofit organization but it's really important to understand that we're run as a social

sections.title: Run as a Social Enterprise
sections.content: organization but it's really important to understand that we're run as a social Enterprise and that means that we're run exactly like a business sales production marketing it's all the same and the funds that come from that are used to employ people with significant disabilities and since 1977 we've been run exact like that never accepting any type of donations or fundraising contributions to uh fortify our operations like any business we have challenges and ours is a big one it's with the state of Illinois which is one of our largest customers and budgetary

sections.title: Budgetary Issues
sections.content: with the state of Illinois which is one of our largest customers and budgetary issues there have not only reduced their purchases but slowed their payments on products they've already bought and we've really tried hard to offset that Gap with our other customers but it's just too big which has led us to try to find creative ways to offset our state business and it's led to some Creative Solutions how the hell did you come up with a GT350 out of all the cars or out of all the things to do fundraising on the idea for the 350r actually came from Ken Bell our executive director when he's not leading the organization here his passion is high performance automobiles he races the cars He collects the cars he's your typical car nut and it was through his long-standing connections that allowed us to secure chassis number 65 of 475 cars produced we decided that creating a fundraiser featuring The Shelby Cobra 350 would be a great way to to fortify our funds and help us continue to employ people with significant disabilities when you guys first contacted me and I've talked to people about this I thought this is kind of a risky fundraising move for a firsttime gig don't you think taking on practical risk is part of any business's operations and try is no different but as a nonprofit We realize that we have an extremely exciting prize in the 350r it's a car that's on any Buff's most wanted list we think the risk is there but it's acceptable you guys are a local non-for-profit company which most people don't know about in all fairness so when they see this on the internet they're going to think it's a total scam so what do you do to kind of address that hey I understand that like any fundraiser there's always some worry or concern that the funds are not reaching the people that it's designed to reach I want to tack that head on the biggest expense we have is the cost of

sections.title: Cost of the Car
sections.content: reach I want to tack that head on the biggest expense we have is the cost of the car but we've purchased the car we possess the car it is here in our facilities after that it is marketing

sections.title: Marketing Expenses
sections.content: possess the car it is here in our facilities after that it is marketing expenses and some small Administration fees to operate the fundraiser after that everything goes to our mission to employ people with significant disabilities including wounded veterans that's it so here's what we want to accomplish we want to raise $250,000 via ticket sales we want to limit our expenses including the cost of the car to no more than $90,000 then 100% of the proceeds will go to the continued employment of people with severe disabilities including wounded veterans [Music]

sections.content: I was approached by a couple brand experts from YouTube and they said what are you doing with your subscribers your followers how are you converting those people into money then he said Dr Goose come on you know people like products people are here to buy stuff they don't just want to watch videos it it's time to start merchandising making your own clothing company uh selling mystery boxes of different merchandise that's all people want and then he looked me in the eye and he said how can you go to sleep at night knowing you only have 16 followers on Twitter nobody's hashtagging you you're a nobody that's when it started to hit home I said Cody for a 12-year-old you're pretty smart I mean you play video games on YouTube and make millions of dollars and here I am scraping by it just clicked it's time to start merchandizing it's time to take it to the next level it's time to take my Twitter followers My My subbies All That stuff and take that Revenue that they're giving me from merchandising and Views and buy things they can't have and then show it off [Music] online welcome to the I plunge SG the world's most Innovative plunger designed and engineered right here in America it's a competitive market out there to be certain our research and development team in coordination with marketing understands that buying a plunger these days isn't like it used to be the youth Market wants customization they want a modular product they can make their own we understand the I plunger SG doesn't stop with us that's why we partnered up with licensed aftermarket companies that can help you take your ey

sections.title: Innovative Engineering in Plunger Design
sections.content: partnered up with licensed aftermarket companies that can help you take your ey plunger to the next level from a carbon fiber handle to an FRP base really the sky the limit it doesn't stop there when you think of the iung SG you think of Engineering in Innovation we've worked with aerodynamicists to check and measure cfm's air flow across the front and the back of this plunger secondly we've worked closely with Engineers from Bridgestone and sumomo Chemical Corporation most en biggest fear during plunging is heat cycling is the rubber compound going to break down so what we've done is we've managed to monitor temperatures at the base and the glands of the plunger rubber material through extended development we found that at around 100 ppms that the base material starts to overheat our solution a copper core it helps to dissipate the heat give the user a more even plunge more confidence critically the design and ergonomics are Paramount to our brand identity we brought in top level Engineers from Vehicles such as the Chevy Spark the datu and Chrysler PT Cruiser to ensure that the overall quality and experience of the ion just G is up to your standards [Music] [Applause] [Music]

sections.title: Final Thoughts
sections.content: this final thoughts on on the Porsche Panamera e hybrid and 4 SE hybrid first off huge thanks to Frank and Calvin our Porsche reps who per usual give us great technical support so what do you need to know well the reason you buy the E hybrid variants of this car whether it be the turbo the four or the S is active ride it is one of the most impressive electromechanical suspension systems I've ever used its ability to hydraulically control Each corner independently and essentially eliminate body lean pitch and dive and both provide excellent body control and tremendous ride quality is something I've never experienced before it gives this car just incredible flexibility you want to drive it fast on a back road you can you want to drive 175 milph in complete comfort you can it is very very impressive the six-cylinder paired with the Hybrid drivetrain is also pretty good it really is it's very seamless it produces Oodles of power and you never notice it which is exactly what you want in a regular drivetrain for a big executive sedan it falls into the background it's engaging when it needs to be it's quick when it needs to be and it's smooth when it needs to be so what are the cons of the car well other than some of the size requirements and all that other stuff which is totally personal preference and use case based it's price this is more money than a 7 Series or a S-Class and it is way more money than an M5 or E63 does it do Luxury and Sport exceptionally well and combine both yes but you are paying for it again for a Panamera 4 SE hybrid by the time you have one well equipped it's $160,000 is and historically these don't have the best residual values which means your cost to own is going to be high but if you're one of those sections.title: Interior Impressions
sections.content: the chevrolet corvette c606 to many despite this car being nearly two generations old is still the corvette to have it's powered by the ls7 a 7 liter push rod v8 that winds out to 7000 rpm makes 505 horsepower and 470 foot-pounds of torque so in this video we're going to be walking you through what made this car so special when it first came out in 2006 with the help from general motors engineers we're going to be putting this thing up on the lift and then taking it for a drive around autobahn country club before i briefly walk you through the cabin space of the c606 i'm going to walk you through what they did to the exterior the z06 was the first wide body offering in the c6 lineup it is nearly three inches wider than the regular c6 corvette and only comes as a hard top for maximum body rigidity the front of this vehicle has two larger inlets it has a air intake inlet on the top of the hood and the front opening is made a little bit wider to feed the oil cooler radiator and trans cooler this car still maintains the openings in the rear fenders for the brake cooling as well the interior space however is essentially a direct carryover and i'm going to talk about the elephant in the room mark brings this up all the time when it comes to corvette interiors of this generation is that they are subpar or inadequate and i will say this is a peak mid-2000s gm cabin space well i'm not saying the ergonomics are poor but many of the material choices in fit and finish does not hold up to modern car standards it's probably worse than what you find in many modern economy cars but despite that what makes corvettes great is that they are very usable the c5 through c7 from an ergonomics perspective are all largely the same they are fairly large cabins for a dedicated sports car and all of them offer a very usable hatch space and because of the hatch this makes it one of the most practical dedicated sports cars you could probably buy i used my c7 when i owned it as a daily driver for

sections.title: Final Thoughts
sections.content: final thoughts on the c606 corvette i wanted to say this first huge thanks to dan the owner who made this video possible and was kind enough to let us track his car the small block engineering team at chevrolet who spent a lot of time with me my reps at chevrolet like trevor thompkins who's amazing to work with and audubon country club who if you are in the midwest and you're looking to do a track day or track date rental i highly suggest you hit them up so what about the car itself well no surprise the c6 z06 is dominated by its v8 it sounds amazing it feels great and it hauls some serious ass it is noticeably faster than my lt1 powered c7 grand sport in a straight line the tr6060 feels great to use it's relatively low effort the gates are clear and if you work with the fact that you have to be smooth with the car you can haul some serious ass even 15 years later the c6 z06 is still an absolute weapon on the track the steering in the c6 despite being hydraulic isn't particularly fast and does not have that much feel so the c7 eps rack because it's faster and more rigid feels better to use and in some ways translates more feel to the front end and the e-diff in the c7 despite not being necessarily as natural is far more capable it allows you to put power down earlier and in some ways can get you out of trouble but despite that the c6 is a car that when you are going flat out in when you're on track and you're in rhythm with the car a lot of its deficiencies go away and you are just in awe the way the ls7 sounds the way the shifter feels and the fact that you are going ridiculously fast so with that thanks for watching and thank you to everyone who's involved in this video [Music] you

sections.content: [Music] welcome to a video called the worst trends in modern cars now this is a great topic because it's going to get the community involved everybody can kind of throw their opinion at this and after being in and out of hundreds of cars new and old knowing mechanics working in the tech field i feel extremely confident about this list so let's get started all right let's start with a hot topic fake engine noise what is it it's when a manufacturer decides that their engine does not sound good or it's not loud enough for the driver so they synthesize a fake tone and play it through the car's speakers on the interior now companies like blackberry have a piece of cunic software that they sell to manufacturers so they can load it up on a computer and design

sections.title: KE ENGINE NOISE
sections.content: sell to manufacturers so they can load it up on a computer and design all the engine noises they want and then they load it into usually the car's infotainment which handles the processing of it so the the thing with this is modern turbocharged motors really don't sound like anything and you can kind of hear it in racing once formula one went to turbocharged cars they lost a lot of their resonance let me just put it that way so the good thing is certain manufacturers do it really well like hyundai is starting to do it good and you can turn it off through the infotainment other manufacturers like the lexus rcf it's just baked in you can't turn it off and it just is one of these mind-boggling things that they're doing that's mostly unnecessary and really cheesy the next one really tickles me the wrong way and like many things on this list it's manufacturers doing things for the sake of it not actually to improve anything electronic door handles and what is it well it's a handle that goes flush with the vehicle that you can't grab physically until it pops out at you and this has a big wow factor supposedly and all this engineering has had to go into designing this door handle so it doesn't stick or get frozen shut in the winter and they're even doing testing on this the big question is why it's just one more thing to break and with all the money being poured into something like that companies like jaguar and land rover you know maybe they should be putting that money into making their cars more reliable instead of gimmicks let's get on to the next one [Music] ah yes stuck on infotainment screens and what is it it's when a manufacturer decides they no longer want to mold the dashboard around the screen so what do they do they just stick a screen on top of the dashboard problem solved it's the epitome of laziness cost cutting and lack of creativity for a better word now i understand why they do it it's more expensive to mold the dashboard around a screen like they do in

sections.title: OVER COMPLICATE
sections.content: [Music] please this next topic i could go on about for probably 57 hours over complicated technology and spending most of my career and user experience there's one thing i've learned you have to keep it simple the more complicated you make it the worse it is and the more excuses and complaints you're going to get in the car world i really feel bad for new owners especially those that are not tech savvy the biggest thing is there's no standardization and safety systems there's no standardization in technology every car and every manufacturer thinks they can do it better or worse they have asset just a pad of spec sheets so they can sell more vehicles you don't know where things are buried at in a touch screen is it in the touch screen is it in the gauge cluster is it on the side of my seat is it on the center stack to the left of me it is an absolute mess and again some of this stuff is just added there just to be there not because it needs to be i think where you're going to start to go is manufacturers are going to start to make an excuse we don't even need a windshield anymore we're just going to put 20 cameras on a car and then stick a screen in front of you so you don't have to look outside through glass and i i feel like this is a trend that needs to die things need to get simple again [Music]

sections.title: INFOTAINMENT
sections.content: [Music] the next one is a biggie infotainment and it's not that the whole concept's bad it's just usually the implementation is lacking i sat down with my honda acura jessica and she's great she was showing me the new rdx or the acura rdx interface and i asked her a simple question like i asked many people has there ever been a car or truck that you use the infotainment and it was so good that you had to buy that vehicle and the answer 9 out of 10 times is no probably more than that and it's just so telling so many of these systems they're trying to pack 50 pounds of in a 5 pound bag there's so much it's so complicated and so difficult to use when you're driving it makes it pointless not only that they're starting to remove physical controls that we've had forever volume knobs tuning knobs physical controls for heating and air conditioning and moving them to touch screens and this is where infotainment completely falls apart and the worst thing is manufacturers still are not committed to updating this over the course of five to ten years they're making them very disposable and now that cars have telematics built into infotainment which is always connected to the internet what's going to stop hackers from getting in there to totally jack up your car when they can get past the firewall from some exploit in 10 years and they're not supporting it

sections.title: OVERSIZED WHEELS
sections.content: the next one is oversized wheels and tires or big wheel and tire combos and to be fair to manufacturers this is mostly consumer driven they get to the dealership they see those 18 19 20 or larger wheels and tires and they're like whoa i gotta have them well here's the thing tires are a part of the suspension setup and to do it right you have to retune dampers or use adaptive dampers now you're adding more complication and cost you're giving you re-tuned bushings and certain things in terms of design and that's a lot of work and the thing is is that when you get over bad pavement you have less sidewall you're dealing with which means a harsher firmer ride the second thing is it's easier to damage a wheel over a pothole and the last and most important thing that people don't get is the cost you know you go to a tire center and i see people complain that there's they don't want to spend 70 on a new tire get me a used one i don't want to spend 70. go try replacing that 19 inch wheel and tire for 250 and see how it is again it's one of these fads and you know we'll see if it goes away all right the next one is pretty big if you watch my videos and a lot of people complain about this piano gloss black shiny trim on the interior of a car or plastic chrome and i'm just gonna ask you this if you're at home how would you like to have a door handle shiny black plastic or your kitchen table or countertop or anything you interact that shiny black in a high traffic area you know the side effect of this it's going to be constantly dirty and easily scratched so you wouldn't do it at home why would you do it on a car interior surface second thing is the plastic chrome it's plastic that's shiny it's the cheapest material but adds a little bit of brightness and what does it do when you put it all over well something called sunlight shines on it and it turns into a blinding agent when you're driving stupidest trends ever the next trend is turbo everything just put a turbo on it and be

sections.title: FAKE VENTS AND EXP
sections.content: the next trend that is so cheesy is fake vents and fake exhaust tips and you know this has been going on for a while but in modern cars you're starting to see it because with direct injected motors there's a lot more soot on the exhaust so it gets the exhaust tips all dirty and you have to clean it they're always black so instead they're blowing the exhaust on the ground now where you don't see the exhaust and then putting fake exhaust tips on which make absolutely no sense and then you have fake vents fake vents on many cars like the new kia stinger in the hood i don't get it stupid fake vents on like the civics i mean it's just a trend that you're starting to see on more cars that that's a snoozer all right the last one i'm pretty sure everybody can relate with and it's not just the automotive market it's the truth in advertising and marketing and i can't tell you all the cringe-worthy ads and commercials you see nowadays for cars from the chevy commercials where they're basically flat out lying or talking about these awards that mean absolutely nothing perceived quality on a vehicle that hasn't even been out in a year like things like this are just nonsense or the words and buzzwords they're using to describe things everything's premium everything's best in class or best in segment or award-winning or industry first or dynamic efficience or dynamic this all the crap that they spin to make things sound better than they really are and it's just it's silly and i guess in the real world when you're bombarded with thousands of products how do you differentiate yourself well hopefully you're not buying into a lot of the crap but thanks for watching i really appreciate it obviously if you have more add to the list than the comments and then keep in mind you know what these manufacturers aren't trying to do bad stuff they're just trying to make products that people buy some have a lot of heart in them some don't some things people's hands are tied you know government reg

videos.title: Archer vs Joby: Which is the better eVTOL stock to invest in?

sections.title: Intro
sections.content: Hey guys, it's Crossroads here. Today I wanted to talk to you about the Eevee Tall space and specifically looking at the two leaders or perceived leaders at this time in the space which is just beginning to develop and emerge that is Joby and also Archer. Now there's a lot of competition in the space but I think these two uh if the industry really does develop and grow one of these is likely to be the Uber in the space and the other is perhaps the Lyft or maybe at best one will be the Coca-Cola and the other will be the Pepsi. Not quite as good but still decent. Now uh why am I

sections.title: Why I'm not investing in eVTOLs just yet.
sections.content: other will be the Pepsi. Not quite as good but still decent. Now uh why am I not in the space? Uh well specifically I'm not sure if EV tolls are really going to be a big part of the future. The problem is we have large commercial aircraft which there's plenty of uh room to integrate developments in that space, but we also have very small drones that can scale up over time. And I think that more likely we're going to have a lot more drones in the future rather than these very specialized vehicles. Case in point, this was all the rage. Uh these uh type of vehicles such as Archamos uh FUV is a stock by the way. uh fun utility vehicles is what these were called. These were an inbetweener uh from ebikes and electric vehicles. A lot of people were excited. There were a lot of different partnerships announced, not quite as many as the EVOL space, a lot of pre-orders even and they ran into a lot of issues. One of the issues was uh and the biggest one really is just they didn't know how to scale this product. But I think they would have also run into this issue of how many people are going to want an in between product between an ebike or you know just a motorized bicycle or the full EV vehicle. Not as many as perhaps were being expected. So this company is basically no more that that play did not work. And I fear that the EV toll space might end up being that. Now I do think that there's a lot more exciting partnerships. There's the beginning of ramp up that we're seeing. uh I I think that they have a chance to be more successful on that side, but the question really remains to be seen in my mind whether this is going to be a legitimate space or not. As a result, I'm not willing to invest capital at this time. There might be a point in the future where I do invest maybe just a very very small bet with high potential of upside, but at right now I am watching from the sidelines, especially in these two companies. Now, what is the

sections.title: The biggest challenge to manufacturing startups.
sections.content: watching from the sidelines, especially in these two companies. Now, what is the biggest issue for these companies? It's not the technology piece. uh specifically Joby actually has some advantages there if you look at range if you look at uh capabilities overall and they actually have five aircraft right now four which have flown versus archers two which just one has flown right now that biggest issue though which I think gives archer the advantage is scalability they've chosen two different ways to basically progress and so Joby we can start with first this by the way has been recycled a little Uh and these numbers are a little bit misleading unless uh Visible found a uh inside interview or something like that. Uh but it shows basically the scale the ramp up that's expected for these. So just 33 of Archer Aviation in 2026 scaling to 465. We actually will look at a slide that shows that it's going to be a lot more than that and Job's is a little bit less. You know, a lot of this is basically the way that things are designed. It's not that Joby is terrible at manufacturing. It's just they're going to run into some issues that doesn't make sense for them to scale out a whole lot on the early side while they're still in the testing and the regulatory side of things. Now, Archer Aviation has some advantages there. So, what is the big difference between these two? Well, first, if you look at the balance sheet, both of these are going to be burning cash for quite some time. They have healthy balance sheets. They'll need to do capital raises very likely in the future, but for now, they are both set. both are close to a billion dollars in cash and that's a good thing for both companies and shareholders as well. Uh that gives them runway for you about two years or so and again they will capital raise at some point. Now uh they also have a lot of partnerships between the two. Joby chose to partner of course with Toyota uh and Stalantis is the main partner as far as automotive

sections.title: Which has the lead?
sections.content: early on that. And as far as uh those future partnerships too, I think the biggest way that you can tell which one of these has the lead though is which can overcome most easily the most challenging hurdle for this type of company which is the issues of scaling and manufacturing at scale. Now why do I think that Archer has an uh advantage there? Well, there's a couple of reasons. So let's look at these specifically. One of these is Palunteer. Now, Palunteer is not the end- all beall. If you partner with Palunteer, then everything that you do as a company is automatically great. No, in fact, they have partnered uh back, I believe in 2020, perhaps 2021 with Lilium. And Lilium is in this space. It's an EVOL uh company, but they are not doing well at all. So that's not specifically the reason but Palunteer specifically and also a partnership with um Anderil as well which are very specific towards automation is very good and Palanteer is actually very good. They they developed a a warp speed uh manufacturing base uh specifically that allows companies to be able to manufacture at speed and at scale and it really helps companies like this really get off the ground but also larger companies too be able to hone those sort of things and they're integrating a lot of neat tools both on the software side but really even more so uh specifically as far as uh supporting the scaling operation that they are trying to do. Now does that automatically guarantee that Archer is going to be successful? No, but I think that the other big factor is that they also are very horizontally integrated. Now, Joby is very vertically integrated and usually I prefer to invest in companies that have that vertical integration. Vertical integration, if you're not familiar with it, is basically you're building in-house as much as possible. It's not that you never partner for other things, but you're reliant on yourself. Now the advantage here for for Joby specifically is that initially yes there might be

sections.title: Why horizontal integration will beat vertical for eVTOLs.
sections.content: so far it's so good, but future products could certainly run into that. So why am I so convinced that horizontal is going to work here much more likely than vertical integration? Two reasons. First, ask yourself in the legacy airline industry, how many companies are vertically integrated versus horizontally? There's basically none that are vertically integrated. Now, that doesn't mean that it can't work. It just means that it really hasn't in the space. And you might say, well, you know, that that's a legacy business. That's just the way it was done back then. That doesn't have to be the way it has been done now. And that's absolutely true. You might say, "But wait, times are different now." And we have a company like Tesla that's very vertically integrated. They partner where they need to, but largely they try to build it in-house, both hardware and software, and they've done that very successfully. But you have to remember Tesla nearly went bankrupt with this strategy. They came within days from actually going bankrupt and it not working out at all. And there were very very well-run, very frugally run. They ran into a lot of issues. And between timing on certain things and just grit, they were able to pull it off. But look at any other vehicle manufacturer, legacy vehicle manufacturing, also EV uh manufacturing. You do not find any other highly vertically integrated companies in the space. It just really seldomly works unless you're an absolute unicorn in this space. And I think the EV tool industry will be the same way where companies that build vertically. It sounds great in theory and if it works, man, it's fantastic, but in practicality, it's usually going to be a lot better just to build in-house what is essential, what is core to your product, and outside of that scale horizontally, which helps you be able to manufacture at scale. Why do you want to manufacture at scale? Well, at some point you need real revenue. And as you begin to build these things out an

sections.title: Acquisition "risk" (Archer)
sections.content: both be able to succeed in that. The question is which can actually scale. Now, the other thing that you need to know for Archer as far as scaling is they've partnered with Stellantis. Now, I would usually take Toyota as far as manufacturing capabilities over Stellantis, but both do okay. Now, what's interesting with Archer is about 20% of their company is owned by Stalantis. This isn't dissimilar to where Rivian was as far as Ford and Amazon partnerships. It happens uh and sometimes that's a benefit. There's also a partnership that they have with Stalantis to help aid in the manufacturing of their units where they give equity increase equity in return for uh helping them scale their manufacturing on the front end up through 2030. Now the risk for that is as that piece of the pie continues to increase by Stalantis they may get to a certain point where they say you know what we just need to acquire this company wholesale. If investors have that happen to them and that's like the worst case, that's actually usually not bad. Means you made some money, just maybe not that extreme high upside that you were hoping for. So that is something to be aware of. Now, another thing that's interesting with Archer is

sections.title: First mover partnership advantage
sections.content: something to be aware of. Now, another thing that's interesting with Archer is we can see some of their recent partnerships show that they perhaps will have the lead in terms of actually launching these things off the ground, though Joby is doing fine work there. Uh this is uh from April 23rd, 2025 and Archer talked a lot about this in their previous earnings call, but specifically they were approved for UAE's first hybrid helport. Now there is a very similar deal that Joby has also in the Middle East too. Uh but this seems like it's actually going to be approved for regulation quite a bit quicker. Uh which is very key for that proof of concept. Now the other part that I thought was very interesting is this article that came out very recently here. Uh May 15th, Arch Aviation selected as the official air taxi provider of the LA28 Olympic and Parolympic Games and Team USA exclusive deal. Now, if you go back to Joby and you look at earnest calls, I believe it was from 2023, they were talking about this potentiality where they said, "Hey, we're aiming to get this and be this partner and be able to actually showcase these at the Olympics in 2028 just because regulation and ramp up takes that long." And they were outmaneuvered here by Archer. Now, does that mean that Joby is doomed? Absolutely not. But it means that while uh these Olympics are going uh on Archer will be the only EV toll that's being used and because it's something relatively unique and novel people will be seeing these really for the first time in use uh a lot of people's eyeballs will get on that product which if they are successful and they need to be successful because if they're not this is about the worst thing you could do then that will breed more success in the future. With that said here's where

sections.title: Joby's FAA progress
sections.content: do then that will breed more success in the future. With that said here's where Joby is at. They talk more about their progress as far as the regulatory approval and where they're at and they're making progress as well. It does take time. It's just not automatic. Um, and but they're doing very well there, too. So, I'm not saying Joby is a terrible investment. I'm not saying it's a terrible bet. I'm just saying that they've made things a little bit more challenging just because of their uh selection as far as vertical integration and what that means for the potential ramp up. And we see these early partnerships with uh Archer though Joby does have some as well that'll just be a little bit later are very key to be able to just be that get that first mover advantage in the space where there is a lot of competition. So let me know what you think in the comments. Do you have it the other way around? Is Joby going to be the Uber and uh Archer here the lift? Do you think it's going to be a winner take all winner take most? Or you think that there's going to be multiple winners? perhaps one of those companies and there's a lot of them out there both public and private uh that I've not talked about you think is going to be the leader. I'd love to hear it in the comments. It's not a space that I know very very well. I just know some of those challenges of manufacturing. I wanted to share that that concern with you guys as far as it relates to Joby versus Archer. Anyway, as always, thank you for watching, commenting, and subscribing.

And uh what they're looking to do is use Yorkville right here. And so the way that this basically works, you can read this, by the way, on the SEC uh website as well. And I encourage you to do so anytime you're invested in a company. Always pull up these documents always will have a lot more detail. Uh this basically gives them future credit. Uh so in essence, Yorkville is a third party that there is is being tasked by Weeble uh to sell up to a billion dollars worth of the dilution of a little bit less than 5% of the market cap of Weeble. So not massive and it can be used for an array of things in the future including acquisitions, strategic moves, that sort of thing. Um what's kind of interesting about it is they're not obligated to do this. I love companies that are generating cash that are about to be fully year profitable um that are growing that are accelerating. That's one of the things I found interesting about Weeble. And then they turn around and do this. Now, I don't mind dilution if there's a reason for it, but there's a lot of other things that they could do. They could, for instance, do a mixed shelf offering. A mix shelf offering is something that uh a lot of companies will do when they want flexibility in the future whether that's for future acquisitions or anything else including sometimes which I don't really like uh buying back their stock aggressively. That's not what hap is happening here but Lululemon was one of those that recently announced a mix shelf offering. Doesn't mean that there's going to be a dilution. It just gives them flexibility usually over a three-year period of time. That's a pretty standard deal. Uh usually the market initially doesn't like it. uh and then it just levels out after that. No big deal. Um they could have done a revolving credit facility if for some reason they felt like in the short term just because uh they didn't have enough cash there. It wasn't necessarily for an acquisition. And the last thing that they could have done is senior convertible notes. Now, there's a lot of other options, too, by the way. they would just be a little bit less compelling. But senior convertible notes basically is offering uh future ownership of the company depending on a certain future strike price of said company. We've seen this, you know, with a lot of companies this year, especially since rates are higher. Uh especially when they're trying to retire some sort of revolving debt. Uh SoFi did this, of course, uh infamously last year. The market didn't like it, but a lot of times when senior convertible notes are offered, it's just kind of a nothing burger. market doesn't overreact or react crazy. So if there has been somebody whether it's a company or individual that is ratcheting up shares that hasn't been disclosed yet that is looking to buy Weeble and do a hostile takeover even though they don't want to sell that could be that they're turning to this as a poison pill. Stock price action usually doesn't like it. It's a terrible option. That's why it's called a poison bill. But man, I don't like that as a shareholder either. So, they could be distressed. They could be desperate. They could also be dumb. Now, that might be a little bit unfair, but you look at all those other different options of what they could be doing right now to do a capital raise. That's based on an analysis of previous Bitcoin cycles which have tended to get smaller over time. But the previous smallest Bitcoin cycle was a 20x return from the trough to the peak. If we can do a 10x return this cycle, that would imply 180K. So that's kind of our guidepost for this year. Uh again, liquidity and technicals could change that, but that's my base case is 180 for this year. For those advisers taking a longer term perspective, we benchmark Bitcoin against gold.
